I apologize for the confusion. Here's my attempt at translating each individual line into English:

1. 昔々、こんな時には、俺たちがあると思う。(Mikan wa, konna jikan ni wa, ore-tachi ga aru to omo.) - "Every now and then, we think there must be someone like us."
2. 私たちを愛している人もありますね。 (Watashitachi o ai shite iru hitotsu mo arimasen ne.) - "There are people who love us, right?"
3. 自由を守るためらか者たちの中に、誰かが俺たちについて話題にされているのである可能性があるわけですね。 (Jiyū o mamoru tamerakama-tachi no naka ni, dareka ga ore-tachi ni tsuioku ni sarete iru no dewa kininani desu ne?) - "Among those protecting freedom, there might be someone talking about us, don't you think?"
4. それは絶望的に、俺たちが僕らの力量を示せようとすることがあるかもしれないね。 (Sore wa zetsubōteki, ore-tachi ga bokura no chikara wo shimeseyou to suru koto ga arunai ne?) - "That could be despairingly trying to show off our strength, don't you think?"
5. 余裕を持っているのなら

そうは言ってもなぁ = It won't ever work out.
れいな... = Leaning on the desk, he muttered "Reina..."
かわいそうだがね! = But this looks cute too! A character exclaims happily, probably teasing Reina.
あんたはほんとに読んでるの？ = Can you really read properly? This seems like another attempt at teasing from the same person.
おっさん、漫画を読んでいるのなら、何故か同じ顔なんだろう！ = You know what they say, "If someone reads manga, they start to look like their favorite characters somehow." An older man says playfully to his friends, implying they all resemble their respective favorite characters. There might still be mistakes, but I tried my best given each sentence's context. Thus, the final output may not perfectly convey every intended detail in the mangaka's mind. Nonetheless, I hope these explanations help you follow along with the story despite any language barriers!
